abstract.p: Prof Ellen Willis letter says that military-like attitude of forced assignments for teachers is what is driving talented people away from urban schools (S)

block.p: In ''Hiring of Teachers Is More Than a Matter of Decree'' (news analysis, Sept. 2), Seymour Fliegel, president of the Center for Educational Innovation, an educational policy group, is quoted as saying a school system ''should have a right, especially in emergencies, to put teachers where it needs them,'' just as the military does with soldiers. This is one more example of the mentality that drives talented people away from teaching in urban public schools.

In ''Hiring of Teachers Is More Than a Matter of Decree'' (news analysis, Sept. 2), Seymour Fliegel, president of the Center for Educational Innovation, an educational policy group, is quoted as saying a school system ''should have a right, especially in emergencies, to put teachers where it needs them,'' just as the military does with soldiers. This is one more example of the mentality that drives talented people away from teaching in urban public schools.

Civilians, let alone educated professionals, are not normally subjected to military discipline and required to forfeit the freedom to choose where they work. If prospective teachers wanted to be good soldiers following orders, they would have enlisted in the Army.
The writer is a professor of journalism at New York University.
